metadata.title: Supplementary Information A viral deubiquitylating enzyme targets viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase and affects viral infectivity

body_text.text: (Genecust). The original sequence was optimized for codon usage in Arabidopsis thaliana, and cloned into the pΩ plant expression vector to generate pΩ-HA-CCHFV-OTU.

Infectious transcripts were derived from the full-length TYMV cDNA clone E17 (Drugeon & Jupin, 2002) . The derivatives E17-stop∆, and E17(A/S2) have been described previously (Prod'homme et al, 2003 , Jakubiec et al, 2007 .

To generate E17-stop∆-(A/S2) and E17-stop∆-(A/S2)-C783S, the (A/S2) mutation in which the residues of the PRO/HEL cleavage site (KRLLGS/Q) were replaced by seven alanine residues (Jakubiec et al, 2007) was first introduced into pΩ-140K and pΩ-140K-C783S by site-directed mutagenesis. The BamHI-XhoI fragment was then cloned into the similarly restricted E17-stop∆. The overall structures of all plasmids were confirmed by restriction analysis, and the sequences of PCR-generated DNA fragments were confirmed by DNA sequencing.

2 To generate bacterial expression vectors encoding TYMV PRO (residues 729-879 of the 206K protein), regions of the TYMV genome were PCR amplified from the parental plasmids p Ω -1 4 0 K a n d p Ω -1 4 0 K -C 7 8 3 S u s i n g p r i m e r s 5 ' -

AAGCTAGGAATTCTAGCTGCCTAGGAGTCTTTTG-3'. The resulting PCR products were digested with the restriction enzymes BamHI and EcoRI, and the fragments were cloned into the corresponding sites of plasmid vector pGex-2T (GE Healthcare). The final clones were verified by DNA sequencing and designated pGex-PRO and pGex-PRO-C783S.
body_text.section: A G T T C T A G G A T C C T C A C A G C T G T T A C C C G C -3 ' a n d 5 ' -

body_text.text: Polyclonal antisera raised against the TYMV 66K protein and the PRR domain of 98K protein (hereafter anti-98K antiserum) were described previously (Prod'homme et al, 2001 , Jakubiec et al, 2004 , and were used at dilutions of 1/1,000 and 1/2,000, respectively.

The polyclonal anti-PRO antiserum raised against the TYMV proteinase domain was obtained by injecting rabbits with a mixture of two synthetic peptides (amino acids 751 to 762 and amino acids 865 to 879) conjugated to keyhole limpet hemocyanin. Peptide synthesis, coupling and immunization were performed by Eurogentec (Belgium) according to standard double XP protocols. For detection of the recombinant PRO domain, the antiserum was used at a 1/300,000 dilution. Anti-myc monoclonal antibody (9E10) (Roche) and anti-Ub polyclonal antibody (Sigma) were used at 1/3000 dilution. Anti-HA monoclonal antibody (16B12) (Covance) was used at 1/1000 dilution.

Total protein extraction from protoplasts, immunoprecipitation (IP), SDS-PAGE, immunoblotting and detection of viral proteins were performed as described (Prod'homme et al, 2001 , 2003 , Jakubiec et al, 2004 using either NBT/BCIP or CDP-Star as a substrate.
Total ubiquitylated proteins were analyzed by electrophoresis on a Nupage 4-12% Bis-Tris gel (Invitrogen) using 50 mM MES, 50 mM Tris pH 7.3, 0.1% SDS, 1 mM EDTA as electrophoresis buffer.

Detection of 66K-Ub conjugates following 66K IP was performed as described (Camborde et al, 2010) . To allow comparison of the amount of 66K-Ub conjugates, a first immunoblot using anti-66K was performed after the IP, to quantify the amount of 66K and account for variations in IP efficiency. Quantification was performed using NIH Image after scanning of the immunoblots. Samples were then normalized according to the amount of 66K and were resolved on 8% SDS-PAGE. Immunoblotting with anti-myc was performed to detect myc-tagged ubiquitylated proteins using CDP-Star as a substrate (Roche) followed by anti-66K to verify the levels of 66K.
Healthy or TYMV-infected Chinese cabbage plant tissue (130 mg
body_text.section: Isolation of membrane fractions from healthy or TYMV-infected plants

body_text.text: Protoplasts of Arabidopsis thaliana were prepared and transfected with 100 ng -15 µg of plasmids or in vitro transcripts as described (Camborde et al, 2010) .
body_text.section: Preparation and transfection of Arabidopsis protoplasts

body_text.text: Protoplasts collected 48 hours post-transfection (hpt) were lysed in Cell Culture Lysis Reagent (Promega). Luciferase activity was measured using the Luciferase assay system (Promega), whereas the amount of CAT enzyme present in the same protein sample was assessed using ELISA immunoassay (Roche) as described (Camborde et al, 2010) .
In vivo metabolic labeling of proteins was performed by adding 2. immunoblots. Values were expressed as a percentage of the corresponding value at the start of the chase period.

Total RNA extraction from protoplasts, electrophoresis, and blotting was performed as described (Jakubiec et al, 2006) . The RNA gel blot was hybridized with a digoxygeninlabeled RNA probe as described (Prod'homme et al, 2003) and revealed using CDP-Star as substrate (Roche). Signal was acquired using the Fujifilm Image Analyzer LAS-3000, and quantitation of viral RNAs was performed using NIH Image and serial dilutions of RNA extracts.
body_text.section: RNA extraction and Northern blot hybridization

body_text.text: Structure modeling by protein threading was performed using the HHpred program (Söding, 2005 ; http://toolkit.tuebingen.mpg.de/hhpred), and the metaservers LOMETS (Wu & Zhang, 2007 ; http://zhanglab.ccmb.med.umich.edu/LOMETS/) and PCONS (Wallner & Elofsson, 2006 ; http://pcons.net/).
body_text.section: Protein sequence alignment, secondary structure predictions and structure modeling

body_text.text: Secondary structures of template proteins were determined by the DSSP program from the PDB atomic coordinate files (Joosten et al, 2010) and were retrieved using MRS (Hekkelman & Vriend, 2005 ; http://mrs.cmbi.ru.nl/mrs-5/). Secondary structure prediction of TYMV PRO was determined using the PSIPRED program (Jones, 1999; http://bioinf.cs.ucl.ac.uk/psipred/) and was aligned to the template structures based on the HHPred search results.
body_text.section: Protein sequence alignment, secondary structure predictions and structure modeling

FIGREF0.text: ) was ground in 1 ml of Grinding buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.5, 15 mM MgCl 2 , 1 mM EDTA, 10% glycerol, 0.1% β-mercapto ethanol). After filtration over 4 layers of cheese-cloth and centrifugation (20,000x g at 4°C for 40 min) over a 200 µl-cushion of D buffer (25 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.5, 7.5 mM MgCl 2 , 0.5 mM EDTA, 20% glycerol, 2 mM DTT), the membrane pellet was resuspended in 50 µl of Binding buffer (50 mM HEPES-KOH pH7.8, 50 mM KCl, 5 mM MgCl 2 , 0.5 mM EDTA, 2 mM DTT).

FIGREF1.text: Sequence sets were obtained from the MEROPS database (Rawlings et al, //www.drive5.com/muscle/index.htm), followed by manual adjustments on the basis of the HHPred search results. The consensus PRO/OTU sequence was determined using MView(Brown et al., 1998; http://bio-mview.sourceforge.net). Accession numbers (Uniprot) of the proteins used in the alignment are: TYMV (P10358), Kennedya yellow mottle virus (KYMV) (P36304), Okra mosaic virus (OkMV) (A5JPL3), Chayotte mosaic virus (ChMV) (Q9QCX3), Physalis mottle virus (PhMV) (O91260), Maize rayado fino virus (MRFV) (Q91TW9), Oat blue dwarf virus (OBDV) (P89920), Grapevine fleck virus (GFkV) (Q8UZB6), Bombyx mori macula-like latent virus (BLMV) (Q6AW71), Apple stem pitting virus (ASPV) (Q64962), Blueberry scorch virus (BSV) (Q2VQN2), Dugbe virus (DUGV) (Q66431), Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus (CCHFV) (Q6TQR6), Equine arteritis virus (EAV) (P19811), yeast
